history.content:
First –– "In future, please do a google search before posting here." –– Nicole.

To answer your question: I have no idea because I don't know which course you're talking about. But in any case, this is something you can figure out yourself. 

Google "HSS Requirements EECS" and you land on this page: https://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide/degree-requirements/humanities-and-social-sciences. It's the first link. 

It has everything you need to answer your question, but you will need to read it entirely and follow what it says.

To answer your question: I have no idea because I don't know which course you're talking about. But in any case, this is something you can figure out yourself. 

Google "HSS Requirements EECS" and you land on this page: https://engineering.berkeley.edu/academics/undergraduate-guide/degree-requirements/humanities-and-social-sciences. It's the first link. 

It has everything you need to answer your question, but you will need to read it entirely and follow what it says.

children.subject:
+1 including that quote that nicole didn’t even say in this context was so over the top... especially when the answer was “I have no idea”... why bother answering? just leave it unanswered next time if you’re gonna be SO condescending. 

you wrote out instructions on how to google, warning OP that they will have to read the whole page... do you not have faith in your peers and think that they can? notice how Nicole, the person you quoted, actually gave a helpful answer

I'm sorry that my answer came across as rude. My intention was quite the opposite –– to make the point that folks should be doing a Google search (or searching on this Piazza) before posting questions that are easily answered by doing a Google Search. I would think that simply providing the link with no other context might be ruder, but perhaps that is not the case.

To explain further

  • I wrote down the phrase I googled just so it's clear how I found the link I found. 
  • I wrote the fact that you'd need to read the entire page only to make the point that important information is scattered throughout that page (and that simply skimming it might not work). For instance, what Nicole said is on the link, but a lot more important information is there too.

There really is no reason for the student answer to be so rude about “Googling the question”, as it is emphasized 3 times. A simple link would suffice. After all, this forum is to get questions answered.

history.content:
I use this L&S page to check courses. Please note that in order to fulfill HSS, the course must fulfill one of the following L&S breadths: 

  • Arts and Literature,
  • Social & Behavioral Sciences,
  • Historical Studies,
  • Philosophy & Values,
  • International Studies.

history.subject: Does an Education course satisify the eecs humanities/ss requirement?
